user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_getattr_:
```c
static lfs_ssize_t lfs_getattr_(lfs_t *lfs, const char *path,
        uint8_t type, void *buffer, lfs_size_t size) {
    lfs_mdir_t cwd;
    lfs_stag_t tag = lfs_dir_find(lfs, &cwd, &path, NULL);
    if (tag < 0) {
        return tag;
    }

    uint16_t id = lfs_tag_id(tag);
    if (id == 0x3ff) {
        // special case for root
        id = 0;
        int err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &cwd, lfs->root);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }

    tag = lfs_dir_get(lfs, &cwd, LFS_MKTAG(0x7ff, 0x3ff, 0),
            LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_USERATTR + type,
                id, lfs_min(size, lfs->attr_max)),
            buffer);
    if (tag < 0) {
        if (tag == LFS_ERR_NOENT) {
            return LFS_ERR_NOATTR;
        }

        return tag;
    }

    return lfs_tag_size(tag);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
    tag = lfs_dir_get(lfs, &cwd, LFS_MKTAG(0x7ff, 0x3ff, 0),
            LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_USERATTR + type,
                id, lfs_min(size, lfs->attr_max)),
            buffer);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the 'buffer' argument is passed as a non-const void* because it is an output buffer that lfs_dir_get will write into (getting the attribute). Rule 8.13 requires pointers be const-qualified when they could be used read-only; here the pointer must be writable, so adding const would be incorrect. (A violation would occur if the pointer were only read and declared non-const when it could be const.)
